properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Northwesth wind gusts reaching 90 to 100 km/h are forecast through this evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions likely Wednesday night and into Thursday. A low pressure system will move through Kivalliq bringing snow and strong northwest winds of 50 gusting to 70 km/h Wednesday night throughout Kivalliq. Poor visibilities in blowing snow are likely with these strong winds particularly at Naujaat. The strong winds and blowing snow may last well into Thursday and then weaken late Thursday as this low pressure system moves through Quebec. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-04T12:32:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T20:33:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2479175223.2020
Area: Naujaat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong to high northwesterly winds will produce blizzard conditions today. Weather conditions will improve gradually later today. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to give blowing snow with widespread visibilities reduced to 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Travel is expected to be very difficult or impossible due to near-zero visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-04T03:59:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T16:13:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3603536167.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm front has brought near 10 cm of snow to the Fort Nelson region today. Further snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm can be expected before the snow tapers off to a few flurries after midnight. The swath of higher snowfall accumulations are expected to fall south of the city of Fort Nelson itself, impacting Highway 97, near Prophet River. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-04T11:59:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T23:24:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0641956050.2020
Area: Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 100 km/h. Time frame: Wednesday morning. Location: exposed coastal areas of the Bonavista Peninsula. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Heavy snow is forecast to begin early this evening over northwestern Alberta and will spread eastwards into northwestern Saskatchewan tonight. Snow will taper off Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-04T13:28:01-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Time frame: overnight tonight into Wednesday morning. Locations: parts of southern, eastern, and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: The snow will be heavy at times and will combine with strong northwesterly winds to give blowing snow over exposed areas mainly Wednesday morning. The highest snowfall amounts will be inland where only snow is expected. Coastal areas will see the precipitation begin as rain or a rain and snow mix tonight which will result in lower snowfall amounts in these areas at first. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-04T10:43:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T18:44:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2922605085.2020
Area: Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An approaching low pressure system will track across Haida Gwaii overnight Wednesday and onto the North Coast early Thursday morning. South of the low, southwest winds 80 to 100 km/h will develop across Central Coast - coastal sections early Wednesday evening and ease Thursday morning. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-04T15:28:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T23:29:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1210340648.2020
Area: Central Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. A band of freezing rain has developed near Peace River and is expected to expand eastward towards northern Saskatchewan tonight. Freezing rain will taper off Wednesday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. A frontal system over the lower mainland will exit the region later today. Heavy rain associated with the system will taper to a few showers this afternoon. Total rainfall amounts of 40 to 60 mm are expected over the lower mainland, Howe Sound and Whistler. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-04T10:41:57-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected. Total Snowfall Amounts: 5 to 10 cm with up to 20 cm possible in some areas. Time frame: overnight tonight into Wednesday morning. Locations: Parts of central, southern, eastern, and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Environment Canada Meteorologists are tracking a developing low pressure system forecast to track across the Avalon Peninsula tonight. The forecast track of this system has been trending westward and forecast guidance is coming into agreement on potential for a significant snowfall overnight tonight in to Wednesday morning combined with strong northwesterly winds. The details are currently being worked on and warnings might be required for some areas in subsequent forecasts later today. The public should prepare for accumulating snow and winter driving conditions for the morning commute on Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-04T06:21:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T14:22:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3826637020.2020
